comments.commentBody: Instead of using "swing oil" or "liquid courage," golfers should use a product called Swing Trust Oil, which is aromatherapy designed for golfers to reduce tension and anxiety on the golf course.

I really like this impass and all the acrimony! This is true democracy at work! There is a fundamental paradigm shift in USA that will be decided next year!

We can today lament, complain, post comments etc but it will be up to voters to choose their own destiny!

My beloved country, we have a 50 year political, social and economic cycle. We had 1960's revolution! Time for 2010 revolution!

What shall we call this change? Agriculture Revolution? Industrial Revolution. No!

I suggest we call this historic events as "New World Revolution", or "Machine Revolution" or "Information Age Revolution" or "Globalization Revolution".

A paradigm shift is happening!

Has anybody noticed the ratio of DVD movies available to streaming movies is about 50 to 1?

After the price hike, both services were to cost about the same. Really? I did the math and canceled the streaming service. My monthly bill (w/ Blue Ray option) just went down $2 compared to the pre-hike pricing, so Netflix just reduced their revenue by 15% and I have to think other people are bound to do the same because it is just simple economics - the streaming service is half-baked at best. While I have enjoyed marathons of watching old Stargate SG1 or 24 episodes from time to time, it comes no where close to justifying he cost.

As far as dividing the business into Netflix and Quickster, I think it will spawn several "What were they thinking???" business books and probably a few chapters on corporate hubris as well over the next five years.
I hope their request is granted. They have certainly waited long enough to get back what is theirs.
I think you get requested to become a member.  You don't asked to get invited.

It is time for the U.N. to clean up the mess and recognize Palestine as a state and move the situation forward.  Israel and the U.S. will never do so.  The fact that the U.S. will not do so is shameful.  The fact that Israel has created what can only be described as a kind of Warsaw Ghetto of Palestinians is reprehensible given recent history.

Netanyahu's speech avoided the central question of why Palestinian statehood is incompatible with "direct negotiations". He failed to give the UN members any reason to block the Palestinian bid for statehood.

In addition it was transparent that his claim for keeping military bases in the West Bank and Golan Heights avoided the reason why residential settlements are justifiable.

IT is time for peace in that part of the world. However Hamas must guarantee that all arms they have will be destroyed. The UN should see to it the Hamas has no power in Palestine.  Let the people live in harmony and the war mongers go away.

There is no easy solution to this problem...two differing cultures with very different beliefs want the same piece of ground for different reasons...really, if you get right down to it they both are like children arguing in the sandbox at recess...only difference is both have the ability to destroy each other....and plenty of innocent people who are just trying to survive have been killed or injured as a result
UN status and statehood carry a burden of responsibility to their neighbors and the rest of the world. Is the Palestinian government and people ready to accept that responsibility?

Prior to the United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine in 1947, the Arab League and local Arab leaders rejected the creation of the state of Israel. How is it that 64 years later the US and Israel can claim that the only path to a Palestinian state is through direct negotiations between the two sides. The hypocracy, inconsistency and injustice of this view is fomenting anti-American and anti-Zionist sentiment in the rest of the world, decreasing American security in the process. Let the Palestinians at least play by the rules of the game you invented. As a true American patriot and hero once said "True peace is not merely the absence of tension: it is the presence of justice." Martin Luther King Jr
Well Abbas and the Palestinian Authority, with their new partner the terrorist organization Hamas, certainly made it clear what they think of Obama! U.S. President used to be taken seriously!
Human right is universal Palestian have their right to be equal in the world. Freedom is the only answer.

It would be nice if the Arab Spring would result in the Arab nations surrounding Israel and Palastine would giving up some of their land to these two nations, to provide each with land enough to provide space to live as well as a barrier. That would be the honorable, generous and peaceful thing to do.  No one wants to give an inch, but they expect Israel to give up the very little she has.  And, yes the Palastinians deserve better, but they have proved themselves to be vengeful, bitter people whose aim is to destroy Israel.  I don't believe they want peace any more than I believe that pigs fly.

The important thing is this: To be able at any moment to sacrifice what we are for what we could become.
Charles DuBois

The real problem between Israel and the Palestinians stems from an absense of palestinian desire to evolve from a rebuilt history of the land in question. It is not a faulty or a lofty dream to seek independence. However, closing eyes and ears to the reality of history in order seek independence without regard for the people on the other side seems misguided. The past has already been written. Israel is a state. What could Palestine become if it recognized that fact?

Each side is s filled with hate and distrust that peace, mutual security and justice are impossible to achieve in this situation. Each side has a narrative of history in which they are the victim of and views the other as hostile.

The US should disengage from all involvement in the Middle East with either side.

In the end this UN effort will have amounted to something a little less substantive than a hill of beans. The Palestinians have a long way to go to convince the Israeli electorate that the latter should feel confident about transferring a strategic asset (land) in exchange for a promise of good behavior. This is something that we in the US and West simply cannot comprehend.

Knesset passage of legislation codifying the division of land will be the litmus test of a deal of course. Until then, the Palestinians have a lot of work to do. I wish them the best of luck.

When the U.S. vetoes the basic right of Palestinians, it will be the end of U.S. respect and influence in the Muslim world. Not that we have (or deserve) much. This veto will make the world a much more dangerous place. It will be seen as a turning point in history and one not for the better.

For many years now, we've seen Israeli hawkish generals-turned politicians acting as if they were negotiating a peace settlement, while doing everything in their power to promote violence. Unfortunately, US has been drawn in as a part of this circus on the minus side.

When I see the images of torn-up enclaves with Palestinians deprived of their basic rights and human dignity, it is hard to imagine Israel as the victim here. Much less as a partner in civilized negotiations, that would lead to a peaceful co-existence between two independent states.

It is time for the US and for Israel to draw up a new political vision for the future of the region. Otherwise, with the process of democratization spreading in the region, it will become gradually more difficult to maintain any kind of stability, and Israel will become even more isolated.

#316 asks: "After all, why are not the Kurds, Armenians or Tibetans entitled to their own state - even if they are not currently in control of the full extent of the territories they claim? "

Armenians have a state, called the Republic of Armenia.

Kurds have citizenship their countries of residence (primarily Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Syria). Tibetans are citizens of China. In theory, at least, they have all of the rights (which exist in theory, too) of all other citizens of these countries. Is Israel willing to grant citizenship to all of the residents of the West Bank and Gaza?

(continued from prior over-the-limit comment) The Palestinians have finally called Israeli's bluff, for the large part changing to a policy of non-violence over the past 6 years. But doing so will never be good enough, because violence isn't the issue, it's only a pretense not to negotiate. The real issue is land; the Israelis have it and don't want to give up their dream of a Jewish state in Judea and Samaria. The messed up part is all of this could be changed, were the people holding the reins of power behaving rationally. But I think there are other state players in this mix that encourage the current cauldron's continued boiling, because it is in their own complex geopolitical and domestic interests to do so. The Jews have been sacrificed on the world altar once before.  They can never fully atone to Christian and Muslim perceptions of them as the killers of Jesus, and to oppressed 3rd worlders as the source of the scourge of capitalism. The only thing that stands in the way of such a sacrifice happening again is Jewish self-delusion that the words "never again" have any real meaning to anyone else living on a planet that has seen the continual repetition of history, in no particular order, as comedy, tragedy and farce. They need to recognize the situation and behave (now we're in a Hollywood Western, maybe Who Shot Liberty Valance?) as smart bankers or traders would who have their backs against the wall, and make a deal. Because the sheriff is wounded and severely compromised, and might not be able to rescue them from the coming lynch mob and the other cattlemen providing the guns and ammunition.

Good luck Palestinians. I felt your energy and emotions today. Even tough our administration declared they would veto your statehood application, I want you to know that millions of Americans are not turning their backs on your struggle.

Today Abbas shamed the United States and definitively gained the moral high ground.  The fact that our veto is assumed with a resigned shrug is a testament to the fact that we have accepted AIPAC and its lobbyists as a more powerful force than the will of the majority. Shameful.

One should carefully listen to or read Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech before the UN.  It now goes unrecognized but may be one of the best political speech's in many years.  The audience was largely present and appeared to be intent on what he had to say.  And, as clear as anyone could make it, he fairly presented the many obstacles that lie in the path to peace.  I have never particularly liked the Prime Minister.  However, he was given his chance and accurately described the history of peace attempts in the area.  He presented the actual bona fide concerns of Israel in an unfiltered light.  And he made clear that peace can only be expected to occur when those concerns are addressed which so far they have not been.  He also made clear that he was swallowing his long term aspirations for the expansion of the territory of Israel and offered to give those up  in exchange for real peace.  It is a game changer!  That, along side the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people that we saw today can lead to a partnership of these people's in the cradle of Western civilization and pave the way for the resolution of this 63 year war.

One thing is crystal clear: the US is permanently in Israel’s headlock. Whosoever becomes the US president, he has to toe Israel’s line. Barrack Obama showed some independent impulses at the beginning of his administration. But he too fell in line fairly quickly. The institutionalized anti-Palestine sentiments of the US presidency make it self-evident that if ever Palestine is born, it has to be literally raped out of the US. Then the US will be in the same position as Palestine today – pathetic and pitiful.
